awd_abstract_narration:
As semiconducting devices become smaller and smaller, the question of how electrons move on shorter and shorter time scales becomes increasingly important. One way to investigate this question is to measure the radiation that is emitted by electrons which have been rapidly accelerated, as would typically be the case in a small device with a fast response. In many situations, it is possible to induce this rapid charge acceleration using a very short pulse of light (i.e., of 100 femtosecond duration); in this case, the emitted radiation typically falls in the terahertz range of the spectrum. Measuring this emitted terahertz radiation, a technique known as "laser terahertz emission spectroscopy" (or LTEM), has proven to be a very powerful method for studying many different kinds of materials, elucidating the earliest dynamical processes which influence the motion of charges in solids. However, it has an important limitation: since there is a limit to how tightly one can focus visible light, the spatial resolution of LTEM is limited to a few microns or larger (that is, the size of the optical spot on the sample). As a result, it has not been possible to leverage this spectroscopic tool in the study of single nanostructures, since they are far too small to be individually addressed by the incident light pulse. In this research program, we will develop a new way to apply LTEM which overcomes this limited spatial resolution. Our technique, which is based on scattering the terahertz radiation from a very small metal tip held near the sample's surface, will improve the spatial resolution of LTEM by three orders of magnitude. This will open up an entirely new realm of nanoscale phenomena for study using LTEM techniques. For example, we will study emerging photovoltaic materials, to see if the crystalline grain boundaries have a significant influence on charge transport which could limit their overall efficiency. We will study nanosized electronic materials such as gallium nitride, where surface defects and interfacial disorder are thought to strongly influence their performance. These measurements will reveal the fundamental physics of charge transport in many different materials, with both nanoscale spatial resolution and sub-picosecond temporal resolution.
Technical description: The proposed research attacks the challenge of coupling millimeter and terahertz waves to nanostructures in a novel way, by using a scattering-type near-field microscope to implement tip-mediated nonlinear optics. Our preliminary work established for the first time the feasibility of tip-mediated terahertz generation (a second-order nonlinear optical process). Building on this early work, we will establish nanoscale laser terahertz emission microscopy as a valuable and versatile tool for spectroscopy of nanomaterials and nanostructures. We will develop several new methods for studying material systems based on this idea, including locally applied electric field bias modulation, and tapping amplitude modulation for studying buried interfaces. We will also broaden the scope of these techniques by combining them with a time-delayed pump pulse, for time-resolved studies of the evolution of the terahertz nonlinearities. This will all be done with a tip-size-limited spatial resolution of ~10 nanometers. Our work will bring the full power of both linear and nonlinear terahertz science to the realm of nanomaterials. We will use these new techniques to study several different material systems, including organometallic halide perovskites and GaN nanostructures and heterostructures. As well as answering open questions about the role of nanoscale morphology in charge transport in these important materials, these measurements will also serve as demonstrations of the power and versatility of this newly developed spectroscopic approach.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop new techniques for studying nanoscale materials and structures using long-wavelength radiation.  Typically, it is very difficult to study small structures with long wavelengths, since one cannot focus radiation to a spot that is much smaller than the wavelength. Recently, new ideas have been developed to overcome this limitation. One can suspend the tip of a sharp metal needle just above the sample to be studied, and scatter long-wavelength radiation off of the tip-sample region. By measuring this scattered radiation, one can infer information about the sample, as long as it is larger than the tip. This approach eliminates the wavelength limitation, since it is the size of the tip (not the wavelength) that matters. Using a very small (e.g., 40 nanometer) tip, one can study nanostructures even with very long wavelength radiation. This general approach is known as scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscopy, or s-SNOM.

Our project focused on the terahertz region of the electromagnetic spectrum, where the wavelength ranges from about 0.1-1.0 mm. We have developed several new methods which enable us to use this tip-based approach more efficiently with specific types of materials.  For example, in the past none of these sorts of s-SNOM measurements have been performed with blue light. Because of the higher frequency (shorter wavelength) of blue light, it is even more challenging to couple it efficiently to the small metal tip. We have showed that, if one uses the blue light to excite a terahertz oscillation in the sample to be studied, one can avoid this coupling challenge, since the terahertz vibration produces long-wavelength radiation which couples very easily to the metal tip, and therefore scatters efficiently to the detector. With this trick, one can now for the first time use s-SNOM methods to study materials which are more efficiently excited with blue light. This includes technologically important materials such as silicon and gallium nitride.

In a second project, we explored new ways to study the dynamics of materials after they absorb light. A common method for studying light-induced dynamics in a material is called a ‘pump-probe’ measurement. Here, a short optical pulse (called the pump pulse) is directed towards a sample, where it may be absorbed, depositing energy and changing the material in some way. A certain time delay later, a second optical pulse (the probe pulse) interacts with the same region of the sample. That interaction is changed by the fact that the pump pulse has perturbed the sample, unless the time delay is long enough for the sample to have relaxed back to its unexcited state.  By measuring this interaction as a function of the delay between the two pulses and using ultrashort (e.g., less than one picosecond) pulses, the lifetime of the perturbed state can be determined. Such measurements can also be performed in an s-SNOM system, so that one can measure the fast dynamics also with high spatial resolution. Our new contribution was to realize that the pump pulse need not be focused directly on the small metal tip, but instead could be laterally displaced to a different location on the sample surface.  In this case, the probe pulse’s interaction with the sample (at the location of the tip) would be unchanged by the pump pulse, unless the pump pulse creates an excitation that can move laterally across the sample until it reaches the probe pulse location. In most semiconductors, absorbed pump light frees electrons to be mobile in the sample, permitting them to diffuse away from the pumped spot. The time delay of the pump-probe signal for a given pump pulse shift is a direct indication of the rate of this diffusion process. We refer to this technique as a ‘non-local pump-probe’ measurement. It will be of particular value in studying materials where the transport of photo-excited charges is anisotropic, meaning that it is not the same in all directions within the sample. Such systems could include nanostructures such as nanowires, or samples with complicated crystal structures such as metal halide perovskites which are of particular interest these days for light harvesting applications, or in two-dimensional materials where grain boundaries between crystalline domains can be the limiting factor in charge transport.

This project has significant intellectual merit because the new experimental techniques can reveal information about materials that may be difficult to obtain in other ways.  The broader impact lies on the technological relevance of the materials that can now be studied, and the impact that this new information will have on their eventual use in functional devices.
